title: Hit and Run
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: The lights changed and he chugged forward. He took a left at Meadowbank towards the east end of Holyrood Park. Road still closed.

title: Hit and Run
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: He'd forgotten all about the other end because he'd never had reason to come that way. There was a way up from Holyrood Park, the Mackies must've used that.

title: Hit and Run
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: That was at approximately 1.50 a.m. Fingertips is some twenty or thirty minutes' walk from where Mr Whitehouse was found, the direct route between the two places passing through Holyrood Park, and we would ask if any revellers or late-night drivers saw the deceased or anything at all suspicious anywhere along that route, that they contact the police immediately.'

title: Hit and Run
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: Billy could hear the faint sound of traffic in the distance, over the embankment. He could see right down to Holyrood Park, just wildlife and darkness. The stars still sparkled overhead.

title: Hit and Run
author: Johnstone, Doug
snippet: He realised where they were. A ruined chapel loomed over them on the left, the well-manicured lawn of Holyrood Park on the other side. They'd be home in a few minutes.

title: The Magicians of Edinburgh
author: Butlin, Ron
snippet: The Year of the Homecoming was 2009, when Scots from all over the world were encouraged to return to their homeland to visit. Among other events there was a march down the Royal Mile and a massive gathering in Holyrood Park, at which several couples were married. Homecominginternet.
